ChestLVInclineBenchPress.name: Lever Incline Bench Press
ChestLVInclineBenchPress.preparation: Lie supine on incline bench with upper chest under lever bar. Grasp lever bar with wide oblique overhand grip.
ChestLVInclineBenchPress.execution: Press bar until arms are extended. Lower weight to upper chest. Repeat.
ChestLVInclineBenchPress.comments: Range of motion will be compromised if grip is too wide. See Lever Incline Bench Press improvised on older equipment and exercise performed with parallel grip. Also see Bench Press Analysis.

ChestLVParallelGripInclineBenchPress.name: Lever Parallel Grip Incline Bench Press
ChestLVParallelGripInclineBenchPress.preparation: Lie supine on incline bench with parallel lever bars out to sides of rib cage. Grasp parallel handles.
ChestLVParallelGripInclineBenchPress.execution: Press lever bars up until arms are extended. Lower weight toward upper chest. Repeat.
ChestLVParallelGripInclineBenchPress.comments: Seat should be adjusted so handles are to sides of lower chest. Parallel grip tends to place shoulders in a more stable position, with arms closer to sides, which may be more ideal for those with certain shoulder issues. Also see exercise performed with standard grip providing greater emphasis on chest development. Also see Bench Press Analysis.

ChestLVInclineChestPress.name: Lever Incline Chest Press
ChestLVInclineChestPress.preparation: Sit on seat with upper chest just above grips on lever. If available, push foot lever until handles are within grasping range. Grasp handles with wide oblique overhand grip and position elbows out to sides. Release foot lever.
ChestLVInclineChestPress.execution: Press lever until arms are extended. Return weight until shoulders or chest feels slightly stretched. Repeat.
ChestLVInclineChestPress.comments: Some machines have foot levers to position handles in a more comfortable starting and ending position. If foot lever is available, engage it before releasing grips. Range of motion will be compromised if grip is too wide. Also see exercise performed with parallel grip and exercise performed on alternative machine.

ChestLVAlternatingInclineChestPress.name: Lever Alternating Incline Chest Press
ChestLVAlternatingInclineChestPress.preparation: Sit on seat with upper chest just above grips on lever. Grasp grips with wide overhand grip and position elbows out to sides.
ChestLVAlternatingInclineChestPress.execution: Press one lever until arm is extended. Return lever back down until chest muscle is slightly stretched. Repeat with opposite arm, alternating between sides.
ChestLVAlternatingInclineChestPress.comments: Range of motion will be compromised if grip is too wide.

ChestLVParallelGripInclineChestPress.name: Lever Parallel Grip Incline Chest Press
ChestLVParallelGripInclineChestPress.preparation: Sit on seat with lower chest at height of parallel handles. If available, push foot lever until handles are within grasping range. Grasp parallel handles.
ChestLVParallelGripInclineChestPress.execution: Press lever bars up until arms are extended. Return weight until shoulders or chest feels slightly stretched. Repeat.
ChestLVParallelGripInclineChestPress.comments: Some machines have foot levers to position handles in a more comfortable starting position. If available, push lever with foot, grasp bar, and release foot lever. Seat should be adjusted so handles are to sides of lower chest. Parallel grip tends to place shoulders in a more stable position, with arms closer to sides, which may be more ideal for those with certain shoulder issues. Also see exercise performed with standard grip providing greater emphasis on chest development.

ChestLVInclineFly.name: Lever Incline Fly
ChestLVInclineFly.preparation: Lie supine on bench. Position inside of forearms under roller pads with arms out to each side. Slightly bend elbows and internally rotate shoulders so elbows are back.
ChestLVInclineFly.execution: Raise lever upward and together in hugging motion. Lower weight until slight stretch is felt in chest or shoulder. Repeat.
ChestLVInclineFly.comments: Elbows should be pointing downward at bottom of motion and outward on top of motion.
